subject: Art & Design
title: Palladio and the Villa: Classical Rebirth
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Palladio and the Villa: Classical Rebirth.

hook.text: The White House, Monticello, and countless stately homes share one ancestor: Andrea Palladio's 16th-century villas.

buildup.text: Palladio studied Roman ruins and created a pattern book: symmetrical facades, temple porticos, and proportional rooms.

discovery.text: His book, 'Four Books of Architecture,' became the most influential architecture manual ever published.

twist.text: Palladianism traveled worldwide: English country houses, American government buildings.

climax.text: Thomas Jefferson was so obsessed with Palladio that he called his book 'the Bible' of architecture.

punchline.text: Palladio wrote the rulebook. Three centuries of architects followed it.

quiz.question: What made Palladio's 'Four Books of Architecture' so influential?
options: It codified classical rules into a pattern book adopted worldwide
It was the first book ever printed
It introduced the concept of skyscrapers
